results.title: Rescue 036
results.creator_credit: Greg Parry and Australia. Dept. of Defence. Public Relations
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Sentinel”.
The Army Aviation Centre at Oakey, Queensland, has more helicopter movements per year than any other airfield in Australia. Therefore the potential of aircraft accidents is great. The Army Aviation Corps have devised a crash rescue system designed to provide medical assistance to crash victims in the shortest possible time.

results.title: Malaria: the recurring enemy
results.creator_credit: Vincent Donovan and Department of Defence Public Relations
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Sentinel”.
Malaria has again become a major world health problem. Strains of malaria parasite have been resistant to drugs and species of anopheles mosquito have developed a tolerance for insecticides. Although research is being carried out aimed at defeating the disease, it still poses a threat to some areas of Australia. Features some black and white sequences. Commentary by Roger Newcombe.

results.title: Sappers K9: the dogs of war
results.creator_credit: Vincent Donovan and Australia. Dept. of Defence. Public Relations
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Sentinel”.
Concealed explosives have maimed and killed Australians in military conflict and society because they do not necessarily incorporate metallic components and are undetectable by conventional machines. The use of a special breed of German Shepherd dog by the Royal Australian Engineers promises greater security.

results.title: Limiting the goblin
results.creator_credit: Vincent Donovan and Australia. Dept. of Defence
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Sentinel”.
The unidentified submarine intruder known as “the Goblin” is no longer free to trespass at will in Australia’s waters. The “Barra” sonobuoy, the world’s most advanced submarine detection device is now in operation with the Royal Australian Air Force.

results.title: The Charge at Beersheba
results.creator_credit: Greg Parry and Australia. Dept. of Defence
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Sentinel”.
The last great cavalry charge in history, at Beersheba (Israel) in 1917, by the AIF Light Horse, is still celebrated today. The charge is regarded as an achievement in the history of the 12/16 Hunter River Lancers, based at Tamworth in New South Wales. The unit, comprising Army Reservists, has strong traditions spanning a period of almost one hundred years. The regiment celebrates the charge annually with a formal dinner. The traditions of the 12/16 HRL are upheld by an active Regimental Association formed by veterans of past campaigns. Because of the keen interest in horsemanship displayed by the veterans, many of the Army Reservists in the regiment have taken to learning the skills associated with Light Horse cavalry. Commentary by Peter Gwynne, cinematography by Phil Hobson.

results.title: Solar oil
results.creator_credit: Vincent Donovan and Australia. Dept. of Defence. Public Relations
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Sentinel”.
As Australian oil reserves recede, many scientists are turning to the sun for a solution in the looming energy crisis. In Australia, scientists employed by the Department of Defence have been encouraged by their research in a revolutionary form of oil - solar oil. The oil is obtained from a freshwater green alga (Botryococcus) which has the ability to store hydrocarbons direct from sunlight. Its special properties makes the alga an unusual subject of the plant world, and a possible key to energy alternatives. Photography by Phil Hobson, sound by Ron Townsend and narrated by Roger Newcombe.

results.title: F-111 the first flight
results.creator_credit: Greg Parry and Australia. Dept. of Defence. Public Relations
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Sentinel”.
Trainee pilots and navigators undergo an intensive training course before they are allowed to operate the supersonic F-111 strike aircraft for the first time. Shows some of the students on their first flight in an F-111. Credits include: photography by Mal Lancaster; edited by Vincent Donovan; sound by Ron Townsend; commentated by Peter Gwynne and scripted by Greg Parry.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Greg Parry and Australia. Dept. of Defence. Public Relations

results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Sentinel”.
In 1979, the biggest locust plague in 25 years threatened pasture and crops valued at hundreds of millions of dollars in New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia. Army and Air Force units helped farmers, graziers, State, Federal and rural authorities to fight the menace.

results.title: Whether to tell the truth
results.creator_credit: Elia Kazan, Sam Spiegel, Columbia Pictures and Learning Corporation of America
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Searching for values: a film anthology”.
Specially edited from “On the Waterfront”, produced by Sam Spiegel, directed by Elia Kazan, this film explores the theme of conscience and conflicting loyalties. It tells of a young man who painfully gains a sense of himself and of his duty to society at the cost of losing his friends and a familiar way of life. As a dock worker, Terry Malloy is bribed by his bosses to suppress information about the murder of a co-worker in which he had inadvertently taken part. Influenced by the parish priest and his own conscience he makes testimony and is left an outcast by his fellow workers. Based on the novel by Budd Schulberg. Suitable for middle and upper secondary level.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Elia Kazan, Sam Spiegel, Columbia Pictures and Learning Corporation of America
